insights.insight: Ad tech charges $5–$150 CPA for probabilistic attribution; this protocol settles at ~$0.10 per cryptographically verified receipt — a 50–200x cost delta that isn't a pricing advantage, it's a structural difference in what's being sold.

With Chrome completing cookie deprecation and fingerprinting under regulatory pressure, the industry has no cross-ecosystem, identity-free primitive for confirmed purchase events — verified receipts fill that exact gap.

insights.topic: Receipt as conversion proof, not proxy
insights.insight: A DKIM-signed receipt is the conversion event itself, not a modeled inference — eliminating the lookback windows, pixel dependencies, and view-through debates that inflate CPA costs and erode attribution confidence.

Spend tokens carry no wallet reference and no identity attachment, removing consent flows, breach liability, and GDPR/CCPA exposure that make traditional first-party and broker data increasingly expensive to hold.

insights.topic: Cross-ecosystem reach the platforms don't have
insights.insight: Google sees search intent, Stripe sees transaction amounts, Apple Pay stays walled — none see line-item purchase confirmation across vendors; DKIM-verified receipts cut across all of them without relying on any platform intermediary.

insights.topic: Organic geographic diffusion as adoption signal
insights.insight: 21 active metros with a burst-quiet-burst expansion pattern across both urban and rural CBSAs points to social graph propagation, not a paid rollout — the network is self-distributing before it has significant marketing spend behind it.
